IMHO eigenvalues make much more sense in the context of coupled ODEs than in the common geometric example revisited in the video. Consider the following problem:

You're in a financial arrangement whereby you give 25% of your savings (for the sake of simplicity, a one-time inheritance) every year--an account that makes 0.1% interest--to a bank that makes 10% interest from the money you provided, and returns 15% of their account value to your personal account at the end of each year. (The rest of the principal you offered, the bank keeps and continues to grow with the following year's investment.) Yes, you're giving more money than you're making at first, but the bank is making 100x what you would be, so it's a worthwhile investment in the long run--right? How fast is your money actually growing?

This question can be easily answered by looking at the eigenvalues of the system matrix, because eigenvalues of a system matrix are the rates at which that system progresses. The dominant (largest) eigenvalue is around 1.068, implying that you'll be making 6.8% return off the arrangement in the long run.

In this context, an imaginary eigenvalue/rate implies an oscillation, a negative rate implies a decay, and a positive rate implies a growth. It's that easy.

SPOILERS. Here's what I've discovered about the puzzle at the end. Observe that squaring A gives successive elements of the Fibonacci sequence F_n, so A^n = [[F_n-1, F_n], [F_n, F_n+1]]. An efficient way to compute A^n will also give an efficient way to compute F_n.Take the eigenbasis E = [[2, 2], [1 + sqrt(5), 1 - sqrt(5)]]. Now the matrix B = Einv * A * E gives a diagonal matrix, as you see in the video. It's easy to compute powers of this matrix, B^n, by squaring the elements. Taking the nth power of matrices of this form is actually equivalent to squaring the matrix in the middle and then multiplying by the matrices on the left and right, since B^n = (Einv * A * E)^n = (Einv * A * E) * (Einv * A * E) * ... * (Einv * A * E) = Einv * A^n * E. To understand the last step, note that the Es and Einvs cancel each other out when you rearrange the brackets. Finally, we can multiply B^n by E and Einv, and out pops A^n: E * B^n * Einv = E * Einv * A^n * E * Einv = A^n. Which gives us the nth Fibonacci number.

I think I've found a neat proof to show that the complex and imaginary part u1,u2 of the solution x=u1+iu2 to the equation x'=Ax are linearly independent.
If we have the system of differential equations x'=Ax, where A is a 2x2 matrix and our solution is in the form x(t)=v*exp(ht) then we need to solve det(A-hI)=0 to find h (l is the identity matrix.)
If we get complex distinct eigenvalues h1=c+ik and h2=c-ik, then we will have the corresponding linearly independent eigenvectors v1=a+ib and v2=a-ib.
We know that the vectors a and b are linearly independent => det(a,b)=det([a1,a2;b1,b2]) is NOT equal to zero (area of a parallellogram is not zero).
One of our solutions to x'=Ax is then x1(t)=v1exp(h1t) which can be separated into its real and imaginary parts: x1(t)=u1+iu2.
We need to show that det(u1,u2) is NOT equal to zero. if we calculate this determinant and do alot of algebra we will end up with something neat: det(u1,u2)=exp(2ct)*det(a,b). exp(2ct) cannot be zero and det(a,b) can neither be zero because of the fact above which proves that u1,u2 are linearly independent.

If someone is interested in a solution for the problem at the end of the video, just have a look at the detailed explanation on how to solve the problem below (sorry for my bad english):
PS: If you first want to try it by yourself and understand it by yourself the following idea is everything you need:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diagonalizable_matrix#An_application







A to the power of k calculates the fibonacci series. It would be nice to calculate without any run-time effort the k-th power of A instead of handling dozens of matrix multiplications of the type A*A*A..., which is why we want to find another way to simplify the calculation.

The given eigenvectors in the excercise are linearly independet, which means, we can build up an eigenbasis (a basis, only using eigenvectors) of the vector space of A (which is R^2). This is useful because we can now use this basis to replace the transformation of A with an equal transformation, which is easier to calculate with.

So how do we do that? Im first going to explain, what we are going to do and at the end, why it simplifies our calculation.
We represent a given vector which should be transformed using the basis of eigenvectors.
In other words, we transform a vector with a matrice into a linear combination of eigenvectors. To describe this matrice we describe the standard basis vectors of the R^2-space using B.
Then, we multiply the output of our first step with a matrice, which describes the transformation of A for vectors related to the eigenbasis.
Afterwards we transform the result back into a vector based on the basis of A.

What we basically did, was: A*v = ((GoBackToA)*(ActuallyCalculate"*v")*(TransformToEigenBasis))*v.
It should be obvious by now, that (GoBackToA) equals (TransformtoEigenBasis^-1) and
A equals (GoBackToA)*(ActuallyCalculate)*(TransformToEigenBasis).
So why does this help? Well first let's have a look at the nice representation of A^k here.

A^k = ((GoBackToA)*(ActuallyCalculate)*(TransformToEigenBasis))^k =
((TransformToEigenBasis^-1)*(ActuallyCalculate)*(TransformToEigenBasis))^k = ?

==> (TTE := TransformToEigenBasis, AC := ActuallyCalculate, I2 := IdentityMatrice (2-dimensional))
(TTE^-1 * AC * TTE) * (TTE^-1 * AC * TTE) * (TTE^-1 * AC * TTE) ... (TTE^-1 * AC * TTE) * (TTE^-1 * AC * TTE) =
TTE^-1 * AC * (TTE * TTE^-1) * AC * (TTE * TTE^-1) * AC * ... * AC * (TTE * TTE^-1) * AC * TTE =
TTE^-1 * AC * I2 * AC * I2 * AC ... AC * I2 * AC * TTE =
TTE^-1 * AC^k * TTE

And here is the clue. AC^k is in contrary to A^k very easy to compute. AC is a matrice which represents the transformation of A in terms of an eigenbasis. Vectors of an eigenbasis can be represented by a linear combination of eigenvectors. Eigenvectors only get scaled when they are multiplied with A.
Which is why a transformation, where each coordinate of the transformed vector is based on a linear combination of eigenvectors, only scales those coordinates - notwithstanding if the vector, which is transformed is an eigenvector or not. This leads to the conclusion that AC has to be diagonal. AC^k is thus very easily calculated by taking every entry unequal to zero to the power of k.

There is a mathematical theorem, which claims the following: A is diagonalizable if the dimension of each eigenspace (the so called geometric multiplicity) equals the so called algebraic multiplicity (multiplicity of the eigenvalue in the characteristic polynomial) of its eigenvalue.
Furthermore (real) symmetric matrices are always diagonalizable.

There's a nice closed formula for powers of 2x2 matrices having determinant -1 (as is the shear case):

A^n = P_{n−1}(t)*A + P_{n−2}(t)*I

where t is the trace(A)/2, and P_n is the nth Pell Polynomial. It can be proved by induction.
E.g. see lemma 5 in here http://pcmap.unizar.es/~jaca2016/PDFXIII/bozzini.pdf

Pell polynomials are strictly connected to fibonacci polynomial; following the subscript convention of the paper, P_n(x/2) = F_{n+1}(x). In our case t = 1/2, and hence P_n(t)=F_{n+1}(1) which is just the (n+1)-th Fibonacci number F_n (F_0 = 0; F_1 = 1; F_2 = 1; F_3 = 2; and so on)
Thus A^1 = F_1 * A + F_0 * I = A + 0I = A = [[0, F_1], [F_1, F_1]]
Thus A^2 = F_2 * A + F_1 * I = A + I = [[F_1, F_1], [F_1, F_1+F_1 = F_2]]
Notice that since the sum of consecutive fibonacci elements is still a fibonacci element, the diagonal elements are also always fibonacci element.
hence
A^3 = F_3 * A + F_2 * I = [[F_2, F_3] [F_3, F_3 +F_2]] = [[F_2, F_3] [F_3, F_4]]
and by induction
A^n = [[F_{n-1}, F_n] [F_n F_{n+1}]]

Eigen Value = Characteristic Value of the transformation - which makes sense - Along some or all directions, the transformation scales by the characteristic value or values.

Eigen Vectors = Characteristic Vectors of the transformation - the vectors that only get scaled and not rotated by a transformation, characteristic vectors are associated with a particular characteristic value.

Together, the characteristic values and characteristic vectors show the properties (characteristics) of the transformation. I think for any transformation with some characteristic values and the associated characteristic vectors, they help to classify or categorize a transformation.

Two different transformations can have the same characteristic values/vectors.

They tell us something about how similar two transformations are. E.g. If two transformations have the same characteristic vectors and different characteristic values, then perhaps they are scaled versions of each other.

Especially in functional programming languages, where you can't just save tons of variables, you don't save a whole sequence, but only a relevant window. Same principle for fibonacci sequence, just with 2 values:
You start with [1, 2] (not [1, 1] for explanation purposes). You calculate 3 as the following value, then shift the window, making the 2, which was the second value, now the first value, put the 3 into the second value to get [2, 3] as the new window and drop the 1. Next window would be [3, 5] and you drop the 2 etc.
